an7.55:4.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you seven places people are reborn, and extinguishment without grasping.
an7.55:4.2: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
an7.55:4.5: “And what are the seven places people are reborn?
an7.55:5.1: Take a mendicant who practices like this:
an7.55:5.2: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’ They gain equanimity.
an7.55:5.3: They’re not attached to life, or to creating a new life. And they see with right wisdom that there is a peaceful state beyond.
an7.55:5.4: But they haven’t completely realized that state. They haven’t totally given up the tendencies of conceit, attachment to life, and ignorance.
an7.55:5.5: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished in-between one life and the next.
an7.55:5.6: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off would be extinguished.
an7.55:5.7: In the same way, a mendicant who practices like this …
an7.55:5.11: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished in-between one life and the next.

an7.55:9.2: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’
an7.55:9.3: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished without extra effort.
an7.55:9.4: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off and floated away would fall on a little heap of grass or twigs.
an7.55:9.5: There it would ignite a fire and produce smoke. But the fire would consume the grass or twigs and become extinguished for lack of fuel.
an7.55:9.6: In the same way, a mendicant who practices like this …
an7.55:9.7: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’
an7.55:9.8: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished without extra effort.

an7.55:10.3: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished with extra effort.
an7.55:10.4: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off and floated away would fall on a large heap of grass or twigs.
an7.55:10.5: There it would ignite a fire and produce smoke. But the fire would consume the grass or twigs and become extinguished for lack of fuel.

an7.55:10.7: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’

an7.55:11.1: Take a mendicant who practices like this:
an7.55:11.2: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’ They gain equanimity.
an7.55:11.3: They’re not attached to life, or to creating a new life. And they see with right wisdom that there is a peaceful state beyond.
an7.55:11.4: But they haven’t totally realized that state. They haven’t completely given up the tendencies of conceit, attachment to life, and ignorance.
an7.55:11.5: With the ending of the five lower fetters they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.
an7.55:11.6: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off and floated away would fall on a huge heap of grass or twigs.
an7.55:11.7: There it would ignite a fire and produce smoke. And after consuming the grass and twigs, the fire would burn up plants and trees until it reached a green field, a roadside, a cliff’s edge, a body of water, or cleared parkland, where it would be extinguished for lack of fuel.
an7.55:11.8: In the same way, a mendicant who practices like this …
an7.55:11.9: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’
an7.55:11.10: With the ending of the five lower fetters they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.
an7.55:11.11: These are the seven places people are reborn.
an7.55:12.1: And what is extinguishment without grasping?
an7.55:12.2: Take a mendicant who practices like this:
an7.55:12.3: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’ They gain equanimity.
an7.55:12.4: They’re not attached to life, or to creating a new life. And they see with right wisdom that there is a peaceful state beyond.
an7.55:12.5: And they have totally realized that state. They’ve completely given up the tendencies of conceit, attachment to life, and ignorance.
an7.55:12.6: They’ve realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having achieved it with their own insight due to the end of defilements.
an7.55:12.8: This is called extinguishment without grasping.
an7.55:12.9: These are the seven places people are reborn, and extinguishment without grasping.”
